column4: Can someone here help me modify my /boot/grub/menu.lst to include a new Linux distro I installed on another partition? I'm close but I need some help.
can you please show us your fdisk -l /dev/hd<whatever> and menu.lst via paste.ubuntu.com ?
Sure thing, hang on...
amenado: OK, here's my fdisk and menu.lst output: http://pastebin.com/d5d8aab87
So do I even need that "root=..." line at all? Why is the Ubuntu one so arcane?
you're having it boot from a swap... you likely want (hd0,4) (hda5 looks like the / of pclinuxos)
Yes, hda5 is the root of the new distro. So I should be using (hd0,4) and not (hd0,2)? Please explain what the 2 and the 4 are if they don't correspond to hda2 or hda4.

hd0 defines first hard drive (hda within linux) the 2 defines hdx3 as grub starts with 0 and linux starts with 1... so hda3 is (hd0,2) which for fdisk is telling me is swap ... hda5 is an extended linux partition, which is (hd0,4) to grub.
make sense>
OK that makes sense. Now what about the "root=/dev/hda5" part--what should that be? If you look at it for my Ubuntu partition it's kinda crazy.
that should be fine... it isn't actualy necessary at all because your /boot and / is the same partition for PCLinuxOS it looks like.
keep it there as it won't do any harm, but I'm fairly sure it isn't needed...
Ubuntu uses UUID's because they are more secure.
OK, I'll give it a try. One last question tho--what is the "ro quiet splash" parameters in the Ubuntu partition lines for?
ls -l /dev/disk/by-uuid ... you'll notice they are symlinks to normal devices.
ro means mount read only... although it actually doesn't, so I don't understand... quiet is not telling you all the boot stuff, and splash is the pretty Ubuntu logo on boot  :)
OK, thanks for the info! I'll give it a try. :)
right click > Clock Preferences
I right-click it, go to "configure clock" and I don't see anywhere, under any tab, how to change it to 12 hour time.
It should be there... I'm not in KDE though... it's Configure Date/Time though... you want 'pH' rather than 'HH'
OK, I found it under "Adjust Date & Time", thanks. But how am I supposed to know that pH is 12 hour and HH is 24 hour? Totally counter-intuitive to me, but I'm not a programmer either.
I forget where I found that out... I think it is defined if you hit "Help" or something.
gksu --desktop /usr/share/applications/software-properties.desktop /usr/bin/software-properties-gtk  <-- exactly what alacarte says about it
